national_indicator_available: Financial Action Task Force (<abbr title="Financial Action Task Force" tabindex="0">FATF</abbr>) rating effectiveness
dns_indicator_definition_new: The indicator represents the number of ‘solid’ or ‘high’ ratings in 11 categories (so-called Immediate Outcomes) in the Financial Action Task Force's (<abbr title="Financial Action Task Force" tabindex="0">FATF</abbr>) review of the effectiveness of national efforts to combat money laundering and terrorist financing (Rating Effectiveness).
dns_political_intention: Money laundering undermines the integrity of the financial system, promotes organised crime and weakens trust in state institutions. Terrorist financing also jeopardises security and stability – both fundamental prerequisites for sustainable economic activity and social justice.
political_target: Improvement to at least 8 out of 11 possible points by 2029
type_target: Goal with a specific target value
indicator_name: Financial Action Task Force (FATF) rating effectiveness
postulate: Prevent negative effects on the political order, the rule of law, the economy and society
content_and_progress:
16.4 Financial Action Task Force (FATF) rating effectiveness

The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) is an international organization established in 1989 to support the fight against money laundering, terrorist financing, and proliferation financing (the financing of weapons of mass destruction). It has issued a set of standards to which more than 200 countries worldwide have committed. The FATF Standards comprise 40 Recommendations, which represent an essential component of international efforts to ensure the integrity and security of the global financial system and serve as the basis for national laws in many member states. The FATF conducts regular evaluations in its member states, which not only review and assess the technical implementation of the Recommendations (technical compliance), but also their effectiveness in practice.



The most recent Germany audit as part of the FATF evaluation process took place from autumn 2020 to June 2022. A visit by FATF auditors was also part of the audit process. During this visit, interviews were conducted with stakeholders from both the public sector (such as the Federal Ministry of Finance (BMF), the judiciary, law enforcement agencies, the Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU), the Federal Financial Supervisory Authority (BaFin), and state supervisory authorities) and with stakeholders from the private sector (such as banks and financial service providers, and professional groups such as notaries, tax advisors, lawyers, and auditors). The review process highlights both the complexity and importance of cooperation in combating financial crime within the framework of the FATF assessment. The overall coordination of the Germany review within the Federal Government was the BMF.

The assessment of effectiveness is based on eleven interim objectives, the so-called Immediate Outcomes (IOs), which cover various areas of combating financial crime. These intermediate objectives are:

Overarching

  • IO 1: Risk understanding and coordination
  • IO 2: International cooperation
Prevention of abuse (prevention)
  • IO 3: Supervisory authorities
  • IO 4: Preventive measures by supervised entities
  • IO 5: Beneficial owners
Combating and prosecuting (repression)
  • IO 6: Financial analysis and investigations
  • IO 7: Money laundering investigations and prosecution
  • IO 8: Asset recovery in money laundering
  • IO 9: Terrorist financing; investigation and prosecution
  • IO 10: Financial sanctions; Non-profit organization (NPO)
  • IO 11: Financing proliferation.
Each interim target receives a rating ranging from "low" to "moderate" to "solid" and "high." For this indicator, the total number of interim targets rated "solid" or "high" is reported. Changes, both positive and negative, between the "low" and "moderate" categories, as well as between "solid" and "high" for individual interim targets, will therefore not be captured by this indicator in the next reporting year.



In the 2022 Germany review, four of the eleven interim targets (IO 1, IO 2, IO 8, and IO 9) were rated as solid and thus passed. The remaining seven interim targets (IO 3, IO 4, IO 5, IO 6, IO 7, IO 10, and IO 11) received a moderate rating and are therefore considered failed. The politically defined objective for the next Germany review in 2029 is to achieve a positive assessment in at least eight of the eleven interim targets.



With regard to the FATF technical requirements (Technical Compliance), Germany"s international standards were assessed as "largely implemented." Of the 40 FATF recommendations, none were considered "not implemented" in the 2022 Germany review. Only five of the recommendations were considered "partially implemented." In response to this assessment, improvements were made, allowing two of these five to be upgraded to "largely implemented" in the 2023 follow-up report. The three remaining recommendations, which were only partially implemented, relate to the areas of "Corresponding Banking," "Transparency and Beneficial Ownership of Legal Persons," and "Statistics." Thus, in 2023, 37 of the FATF recommendations were considered "largely implemented" (20) or "implemented" (17).

weather_indicator_1: 16.4 Financial Action Task Force (FATF) rating effectiveness

footer_fields.label: Notes
footer_fields.value:
• Financial Action Task Force (FATF): The most important international institution for combating and preventing money laundering, terrorist financing and proliferation financing.
• Effectiveness: Examination of the effectiveness of national efforts to combat money laundering and terrorist financing in 11 categories (so-called immediate outcomes).
• Passed: Ratings solid or high.
• Not passed: Low or moderate ratings.

footer_fields.label: Notes
footer_fields.value:
• Financial Action Task Force (FATF): The most important international institution for combating and preventing money laundering, terrorist financing and proliferation financing.
• Technical compliance: implementation of FATF standards in national law and through national requirements
• Passed: Largely realised or realised.
• Not passed: Not implemented or partially implemented.
• 2022 Evaluation from the Germany audit (Mutual Evaluation Report), 2023 Evaluation from the follow-up report (Follow-Up Report).

data_start_values.value: Technical compliance = Largely compliant or compliant
Technical compliance = Non-compliant or partially compliant

target_description:
The number of categories rated as ‘solid’ or ‘high’ in the Financial Action Task Force's effectiveness assessment is to be increased to at least 8 by 2029.


No assessment possible. Too few data points.
